predictions.reasoning: Low-merge author (0% across 11 PRs) is deterministic rejection signal per learned patterns. Discord channel fix is focused/narrow scope (+5-10%), but insufficient to overcome weak author credentials. Missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, tests, CI) imposes ~7-8% confidence penalty. No compensatory signals (maintainer label, trusted-contributor, experienced-contributor). Pattern: '0% historical merge rate across 3+ prior PRs face deterministic rejection risk unless compensated by explicit credibility labels or high-priority category with narrow scope.' Discord is not high-priority enough to overcome this.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with 0.0% baseline merge rate. Discord mention detection fix is focused/narrow scope (single component), providing +5-10% boost, but insufficient to overcome first-time author rejection bias. Missing all critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, tests, CI). No explicit size label. No compensatory signals (maintainer, trusted, experienced labels). Pattern: 'First-time contributors with missing critical metadata face significant merge uncertainty.' Baseline ~24% reduced by missing metadata penalty (~7-8%) and lack of compensatory signals → ~16-17% effective likelihood.

Low-merge author (0% across 4 PRs, just below 5-PR threshold for deterministic rejection but still strong negative signal). Fix-type change in critical path (cron/timeout logic) theoretically receives +10-20% boost, but pattern states 'Critical-path infrastructure changes from new or underperforming authors require explicit credibility signals to offset systemic risk.' Author has 0% history with no compensatory signals (maintainer label, trusted-contributor, experienced-contributor). Missing all critical metadata. No category uplift (no high-priority label). Pattern: 'Critical-path infrastructure changes require higher evidence threshold from new contributors; scope risk outweighs category strength.'

Strong compensatory signal: Author has 100% prior merge rate (1/1 prior PR merged). Pattern: '100% author merge rate history (even with single prior PR) signals strong credibility and >50% merge likelihood when paired with focused scope.' Feature addition in high-priority 'agents' category provides +15-25% baseline uplift. Missing all critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, tests, CI) imposes ~7-8% confidence penalty, reducing from potential 65-75% to ~57-67%. Feature classification (not fix) and missing metadata offset some of 100% author bonus. Conservative estimate: 68% (capturing strong author signal while discounting metadata gap).

Low-merge author (0% across 2 PRs). Size label 'L' is strong rejection signal per patterns: 'L size labels provide no merge boost and may indicate scope risk.' Pattern: 'Large scope PRs (XL size, multiple categories, extensive LoC) are strong negative signals even with experienced authors.' Gateway is high-priority category (+15-25% uplift), but insufficient to overcome: (a) 0% author merge history, (b) L size label (scope risk), (c) missing all critical metadata. Fix classification provides +10-20% boost, but does not overcome L size risk. Effective calculation: baseline 24% + gateway uplift +20% = 44%, minus L size penalty -25% = 19%, minus metadata gap -7% = ~12%. Conservative: 19% confidence in closure.

Deterministic rejection signal: XL size label is strongest negative predictor. Pattern: 'L and XL size labels are strong rejection signals correlating with 15-20% merge rates, overriding compensatory signals and creating deterministic rejection risk for first-time contributors.' First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with XL scope and multi-category touch (app: android, cli, agents). Pattern: 'Multi-channel PRs from first-time contributors violate architectural constraints and carry high rejection risk.' Touches multiple component areas. Missing all critical metadata. No compensatory signals (maintainer, trusted, experienced labels). XL scope overrides even high-priority category uplift (agents). Effective: baseline 24%, minus XL size penalty -60-70%, minus first-time author penalty, equals near-zero likelihood.

Low-merge author (0% across 6 PRs). Size label 'L' is strong negative signal (scope risk, 15-20% merge rate for L size). Multi-component scope (cross-channel awareness + conversation context) is red flag: Pattern: 'Multi-component scope (touching multiple channels/areas) reduces merge likelihood by 25-30% for weak authors.' Telegram is mid-priority channel (347 PRs, not top-tier). Feature classification (not fix) reduces boost. Missing all critical metadata. No compensatory signals. Calculation: baseline 24%, L size penalty -30%, multi-component penalty -25%, weak author penalty, metadata gap -7% = ~12-15% effective likelihood. Conservative confidence in closure: 82%.

Mixed signals: (a) Author merge rate 12.5% (below 24% baseline, weak signal). (b) Size 'S' label provides +2-4% boost (XS/S correlate with 26-28% merge rates). (c) Fix-type change provides +10-20% boost. (d) WhatsApp is mid-priority channel (215 PRs). Pattern: 'Authors with 15-25% prior merge rate near baseline benefit from narrow scope and fix-type classification for moderate merge likelihood.' Author at 12.5% with S size and focused fix: baseline 24% + fix boost +15% + S size boost +3% = 42%, but author merge rate below baseline reduces confidence. Missing all critical metadata (-7-8% penalty). Effective: ~34-35% probability. Given XS/S size boost for narrow fixes, moderate likelihood. Confidence: 54% (leaning toward merge due to S size + fix type, but weak author history creates uncertainty).

Established author with high PR volume (55 prior PRs) provides persistence/commitment signal despite 5.5% merge rate. Size 'XS' label is strongest positive signal: Pattern: 'XS size class consistently outperforms other size classes for merge probability (~26-28%), particularly for first-time contributors.' XS label provides +2-4% boost and signals focused scope. Infrastructure fix (CI/testing) is chore-like category with baseline ~24-25%. Pattern: 'Authors demonstrating persistence through high PR volume (50+ prior PRs) show commitment signal and retain moderate merge likelihood even when merge rate is below baseline.' Calculation: baseline 24% + XS size boost +3% + high volume commitment signal +5-10% = 32-37%. Missing critical metadata (-7-8% penalty) reduces to ~25-30%. But XS label and infrastructure chore nature suggest reasonable merge likelihood. Confidence: 62% (XS size strongly supports, but low author merge rate and missing metadata create uncertainty).

No compensatory signals (maintainer, trusted, experienced labels). PR is 'Chore/dependency exception guard' (scripts/docs), not XS size. Calculation: baseline 24%, minus first-time author penalty -10-15%, S size boost +3%, minus metadata penalty -7% = ~5-10% effective likelihood. Conservative confidence in closure: 77%.

Feature-type change (adding logging infrastructure) from unknown author on large scope. No credibility signals. XL is explicit rejection marker per learned patterns: 'L and XL size labels are strong rejection signals...overriding compensatory signals.' Deterministic rejection prediction with high confidence.

PR addresses critical infrastructure issue (#14042 reference): replacing workspace:* with peerDependencies in extensions—systemic refactoring across multiple extension packages. Size label S (+2-4% boost for XS/S classes). Author demonstrates persistence and knowledge of codebase. However, 8% merge rate is weak, and massive scope (18 channels + 9 extensions) is high-risk refactoring. S label and issue reference provide compensatory signals. Moderate merge likelihood given infrastructure importance and author persistence; borderline prediction reflects substantial uncertainty.

Missing all critical metadata (LoC, files, tests, CI status) imposes ~7-8% penalty. Size S provides modest boost but insufficient to offset critical-path infrastructure risk + first-time status. Fix-type classification (+10-20%) and high-priority category (+15-25%) provide uplift, but 'critical-path changes...require higher evidence threshold from new contributors.' No maintainer or credibility labels present. Gateway changes require consensus per patterns. Prediction leans toward rejection despite size S compensatory signal.

Both are single-channel Discord fixes with focused scope. High confidence they address identical issue.

Both PRs fix discord channel logging behavior (guild_id handling). PR #16231 references issue #16207. PR #16283 appears to be follow-up addressing raw event guild_id in inbound message log. Same author focus (discord), same fix category, same XS size class, identical component area. Temporal proximity (15 hours apart). Likely supersession: #16231 may be earlier attempt, #16283 refinement or related fix. High similarity in scope and intent.
